newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Deputy PM Anwar to run Malaysia while Mahathir away.
newsitem.headline: Deputy PM Anwar to run Malaysia while Mahathir away.

text.p: Malaysian deputy premier Anwar Ibrahim will run the country when Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad goes away on a work-and-vacation mission which could last two months, government officials said on Wednesday.

The 49-year-old Anwar will be acting prime minister in the absence of his boss, who will be visiting a number of countries to promote Malaysia's new technology zone, the Multimedia Super Corridor, the officials said.
"There's no secret here. The PM will be going on leave for two months and Anwar will be the acting PM," Nazri Aziz, deputy minister in the prime minister's department, told reporters.
Officials said Anwar, also Malaysia's finance minister, will handle Mahathir's powerful home ministry post as well.
Mahathir, currently winding up a visit to African countries, was scheduled to return home on Thursday and make an announcement about his mission, which could start late May.

News of his impending leave -- reportedly the longest he has ever planned since becoming prime minister in 1981 -- stirred up much speculation in financial markets on Wednesday. Dealers said the speculation helped weaken the local ringgit currency.
Most of the talk centred on whether Mahathir would be testing the governing abilities of Anwar, widely regarded as his most natural successor.
Another concern was that Mahathir's health was failing, although officials firmly denied that the 71-year-old premier, who had a heart operation eight years ago, was ill in any way.
"This has nothing to do with his health," a government source told Reuters.

Transport Minister Ling Liong Sik told reporters Mahathir was scheduled to visit London and a number of eastern European countries such as Poland and Russia to discuss bilateral issues and promote the Multimedia Super Corridor -- a planned high-tech zone which will extend south from the capital Kuala Lumpur.
The opposition saw the move as a ploy by Mahathir to re-assess his own political strength and that of the government.

"You take a step back, watch the weaknesses and strengths in your government while you're gone, and then ponder on ways to improve things. He's right to do it," said Lim Guan Eng, deputy secretary-general of the Democratic Action Party, Malaysia's largest opposition party.
